The computational grid was created using GEFDC (a mesh generator for EFDC) and NOAA’s coastline and bathymetric data.</abstract> <purpose>Estimate flooding due to Ivan and Dennis hurricane events (2004-2005) in the coastal area.</purpose> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>2012</caldate> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <current>publication date</current> </timeperd> <status> <rngdates> <begdate>20040913</begdate> <enddate>20080914</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <srccurr>publication date</srccurr> </srctime> <srccitea>NG-CHC-ADCIRC</srccitea> <srccontr>Provided water surface elevation inundation areas for Weeks Bay.</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>The grid generator for EFDC (GEFDC), capable of producing structured rectangular and curvilinear meshes, was applied for creating a structured grid of Weeks Bay for hydrodynamics modeling. The bathymetry data (detailing the bottom topography with respect to mean sea level) was downloaded from the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration National Geophysical Data Center (NOAA-NGDC) database. NGDC provides datasets of the U.S. coastal zone integrating offshore bathymetry with land topography into a seamless representation of the coast derived from NGDC's hydrographic surveys, multi-beam bathymetry, and track-line bathymetry; the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS); and other federal government agencies and academic institutions. In this research, the US Coastal Relief Model bathymetric data was selected for its fine spatial resolution (84 m x 84 m raster cells), date of production (beginning date: 1999, ending date: present), and accuracy and reliability. The bathymetric information was downloaded in ASCII raster format and was critical for producing one of the main input data required by GEFDC for the generation of the grid: the cell.inp file. This file specifies the interconnection between finite-difference cells, the type of cell (water, boundary, dry land, etc.), and whether it is a quadrilateral or triangular cell. Manipulation of the raw ASCII bathymetry data was performed using ArcGIS and tailor-made C codes. Other files required by EFDC such as dxdy.inp (specifying grid coordinates correspondence to actual geographical coordinates), depdat.inp, lxly.inp (bottom depths for each finite-difference cell corner), etc., were also produced by those tailor made codes. All pre-processing for the generation of the required GEFDC input files was performed in UTM Zone 16N coordinates. Figure 2 illustrates the process. Ocean boundary conditions were set up using LSU's ADCIRC model output for Ivan and Dennis events. Fresh boundary conditions incoming to Weeks Bay (Fish and Magnolia rivers)were estimated using existing HSPF hydrological models developed by Vladimir J. Alarcon in  previous researches.</procdesc> <procdate>201202</procdate> <proccont> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>Northern Gulf Institute</cntorg> <cntper>Dr. Vladimir Alarcon</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntpos>Assistant Research Professor</cntpos> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype> <address>P.O.
